item.title: On-Premise 101 (Part 4): Automating 12 VMs creation on Proxmox with Terraform
item.author: xuanphuc.a1gv@gmail.com (Felix Hoang)
item.description: I’m the kind of person who will happily spend 10 hours building an automation script just to save 10 minutes of manual work every day. If that sounds like you, you’re in the right place.

item.title: On-Premise 101 (Part 3): My "Fearless" NAS Build with Virtualized TrueNAS, ZFS, and Cloud Backups
item.author: xuanphuc.a1gv@gmail.com (Felix Hoang)
item.description: In the previous parts of this series, we went from a single hand-me-down PC to a full 3-node cluster, and then we installed Proxmox as our hypervisor. We even managed to pass through a GPU to a VM for near-native performance.

item.title: On-Premise 101 (Part 2): Proxmox, the "Glue" for My Homelab
item.author: xuanphuc.a1gv@gmail.com (Felix Hoang)
item.description: In the previous part, we covered how I started playing around with my hand-me-down computer and then escalated to building a whole 3-node cluster. It’s been a 3-year journey, and there have been so many changes to the software stack I host. But no matter what, there’s one thing I’ve used consistently from beginning to end: Proxmox (Hypervisor). So before we dive into how I deploy my applications on Docker or Kubernetes, I’ll show you the glue that connects the hardware we just built to all the software we’re going to deploy.

item.title: Automate provisioning Kubernetes cluster on Proxmox with Terraform + Ansible
item.author: xuanphuc.a1gv@gmail.com (Felix Hoang)
item.description: This project automates the provisioning and configuration of a RKE2 Kubernetes cluster on Proxmox using Terraform and Ansible.

item.title: My First Server Was Office Trash: A Self-Hosting Story
item.author: xuanphuc.a1gv@gmail.com (Felix Hoang)
item.description: It all started with a computer my mom saved from the trash heap at her office. It was a standard HP Prodesk 600 G4—nothing special, and since I already had a PC and a laptop, I had no idea what to do with it. Just installing Windows on it felt like a waste. I knew it could be something more than just another desktop collecting dust.
